title-group.article-title: Cross-sectional analysis of sociodemographic factors associated with self-reported and knowledge-based health literacy in Korea using data from KNHANES 2023

abstract.p: Health literacy is a key factor influencing treatment adherence and outcomes. This study analyzed the 2023 Korea National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (KNHANES) to explore the relationship between demographic and socioeconomic factors and health literacy. We examined associations between factors such as age, gender, residential region, education, and income with health literacy, which consisted of 10 questions and 1 knowledge assessment. Multiple linear regression was applied to the sum of health literacy scores, and multivariate ordinal regression was used for the knowledge assessment. A total of 5,713 participants were analyzed. Results showed that age ≥ 65 years negatively affected health literacy scores (− 1.01), while females had a positive effect (0.93), though elderly females had a negative impact (− 1.60). Higher education and income were positively associated with health literacy, with education showing the greatest effect (3.42). Elderly individuals and education levels had the strongest negative and positive effects, respectively, in the Technology and Resources domain. In conclusion, older age, lower education, and lower income were linked to lower health literacy, with gender’s impact varying by age group, especially in digital health literacy.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-08705-9.

kwd-group.title: Keywords
kwd-group.kwd: Korea National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Although definitions vary, health literacy constitutes knowledge of health and its utilization to maintain a healthy state1. Health literacy can influence treatment adherence in patients with chronic diseases, thereby affecting treatment outcomes2. Health literacy is known to be related to sociodemographic factors3 and it has become more prominent with the widespread use of digital technologies in healthcare4. It has been reported that digital health literacy is higher in patients with higher income and education levels, and lower in the elderly5,6. Therefore, it has raised concerns about the digital divide5 and it is expected to become more pronounced as more digital technologies are adopted in healthcare.

Measurement of health literacy is mostly based on self-reported questionnaires. More than 100 measures of health literacy have been developed7 and inconsistency among these measures has been reported. Recently, multidimensional measurement has been increasing and is expected to provide a comprehensive overview of health literacy8,9. In South Korea, the Health Literacy Index for the Community (HLIC) has been developed and validated to measure health literacy in the general population, covering the dimensions of disease prevention, health promotion, and healthcare10.

The HLIC was developed to address cultural differences encountered when applying the widely used European Health Literacy Survey (HLS-EU-Q47)11 to the Korean population, while also encompassing a broader population base10. The HLIC consists of 10 items covering four domains: disease prevention, health promotion, healthcare, and technology and resources. It was validated in a sample of 1041 Korean participants, stratified by age, gender, area of residence, and socioeconomic status, using the same sampling method employed in the 2021 Korea National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (KNHANES)10. The HLIC demonstrated strong internal consistency (Cronbach’s α = 0.87) and a good overall correlation coefficient (r = 0.67)10. Detailed information on its reliability and validity has been reported elsewhere10.

The recent widespread adoption of digital health technologies in clinical practice and research highlights the importance of digital health literacy in influencing clinical outcomes12,13. Sociodemographic factors such as age, gender, income, and education level have been identified as key determinants of digital health literacy6. However, the effects of these sociodemographic factors may vary depending on cultural context and the characteristics of the selected population subgroups (e.g., younger vs. older adults)6. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate these effects in the general population while taking cultural aspects into account. From this perspective, the use of data from the Korea National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (KNHANES) is appropriate, as it reflects the general population of Korea and captures the current distribution of sociodemographic factors.

Interestingly, the impact of sociodemographic factors on health literacy is not consistently reported across studies. A representative example is the effect of gender on health literacy. Findings on gender differences in health literacy are conflicting6 and these differences are strongly influenced by cultural context and age14. Furthermore, the method used to measure health literacy (e.g., self-reported, knowledge-based assessments) can also affect study outcomes15. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the impact of known sociodemographic factors and their interactions across diverse study populations with multiple measures.

In addition, health literacy, especially digital health literacy, is becoming increasingly important in the context of clinical research. A key trend in clinical research is conducting studies within routine clinical practice, enabling the capture of real-world conditions and a more diverse study population16. In other words, it is expected that the importance of health literacy will be emphasized if decentralized elements, or trial-related activities conducted outside traditional trial sites, are involved17. Although the impact of health literacy on clinical research warrants further investigation, it has been reported that limited health literacy is associated with a lack of comprehension of consent documents and increased anxiety. With the growing use of digital communication tools (e.g., smartphone apps) in modern clinical research, participant adherence to trial activities may decline without proper preparation18. Accordingly, a thorough assessment of sociodemographic factors that may influence health literacy is necessary, given their potential to affect both the interpretation of study findings and trial outcomes.

In this study, we analyzed the KNHANES 2023 to evaluate the association between demographic and socioeconomic factors and health literacy. KNHANES is a nationwide cross-sectional survey and is representative of the general population in South Korea19. Health literacy measures were first introduced in KNHANES 2023. Our study aimed to assess the association between sociodemographic factors and both self-reported and knowledge-based health literacy in a population representative of the general Korean population. Given that demographic and socioeconomic factors are generally used as eligibility criteria in clinical trials, evaluating risk factors for low health literacy could help preemptively mitigate potential biases in clinical trials.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The retrospective study was conducted based on the KNHANES 2023. KNHANES is a nationwide cross-sectional survey conducted annually on approximately 10,000 participants19. The sampling frame of KNHANES was based on the 2019 Population and Housing Census in Korea. The optimal number of households per primary sampling unit was estimated to be 25 to 30, considering variance and cost, design effect, and intraclass correlation coefficient. Based on these factors, 576 primary sampling units (192 per year) and 14,400 households (4800 per year) were selected20. KNHANES consists of three component surveys: health interview, health examination, and nutrition survey19. Elements of each component may vary across surveys, and the health literacy survey was introduced for the first time in KNHANES 2023. Given that the health literacy survey was only conducted on adult participants, we included all participants aged ≥ 20 years.

The KNHANES 2023 survey was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (IRB no. 2022-11-16-R-A). The survey was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Bioethics and Safety Act of the Republic of Korea, and written informed consent was obtained from all participants by the KNHANES investigators.

This study is a cross-sectional, retrospective, and observational analysis based on anonymized KNHANES data, and was conducted in accordance with the STROBE (Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) guideline. As the research involved minimal risk and used de-identified data, the requirement for written informed consent was waived by the IRB of Seoul National University Hospital (IRB no. 2051-013-1600).

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The collected sociodemographic variables were as follows: age, gender, residential region, education level, and income level. Residential region was categorized as binary, with ‘rural’ assigned to regions including Gangwon-do, Chungcheongbuk-do, Chungcheongnam-do, Jeonllabuk-do, Jeonllanam-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, or Jeju Special Self-Governing Province; all other regions were categorized as ‘urban’21. (Supplementary Fig. 1) Education level was recorded in four categories: ≤ Elementary school, middle school, high school, and ≥ University. Income level was categorized into quartiles.

Health literacy measures consisted of 10 self-reporting questions and 1 knowledge assessment. The self-reporting questions were based on a 4-point Likert scale (1 = never, 2 = rarely, 3 = sometimes, 4 = always). The health literacy questions were grouped into four domains of health literacy: disease prevention (Q1–3, A domain), health promotion (Q4, B domain), healthcare (Q5–8, C domain), and technology and resources (Q9–10, D domain). A more detailed description and validation of the health literacy questions are provided elsewhere10. The sum of the health literacy scores from the 10 questions was also used as a variable. If a question was unanswered or the response was ‘unknown,’ the answer was counted as one score. The knowledge assessment consisted of a multiple-choice question with four items and evaluated comprehension of the content in a short message service sent by a hospital (E domain). A full description of the questions and knowledge assessment is provided in Supplementary Table 1.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: For the descriptive analysis, participants were classified into quintiles based on the sum of their health literacy scores. Chi-square tests were used to compare the distribution of age group, gender, education level, income, and residential region (demographic and socioeconomic factors) across each quintile. The mean and 95% confidence intervals for the sum of the health literacy scores and the proportion of correct answers were calculated according to demographic and socioeconomic factors. Multiple linear regression and multivariable logistic regression were performed on the sum of the health literacy scores and the correctness of the knowledge assessment, with demographic and socioeconomic factors as independent variables, respectively. To evaluate the influence of the demographic and socioeconomic factors on each health literacy measure and domain, multivariate ordinal regression was performed for each health literacy question. Odds ratios were calculated for each health literacy question using the final model for the sum of the health literacy scores.

Variables, including interaction terms, were included by forward selection. We constructed the models with well-known and more independent variables. The initial base model (Model 1) included age and gender. The statistical significance of adding additional covariates was subsequently evaluated: education and income in Model 2, and residential region in Model 3. The Wald test was used for model evaluation. A p-value less than 0.05 was considered to significantly improve the model. Odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals were obtained from the models. As KNHANES used multi-stage clustered probability sampling, complex survey data analysis was performed using the sampling components (strata and cluster) and appropriate weights provided in the dataset. All statistical analyses were performed using R version 4.4.1 (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria), and complex survey data analysis was performed using the survey and srvyr packages.

sec.title: Disposition and characteristics of the participants
sec.p: A total of 6929 participants were included in the KNHANES 2023 dataset, of whom 5,866 were adults aged 20 years or older. Of these, 153 participants were excluded due to missing education level information, leaving 5713 participants in the final analysis. Statistically significant differences were observed in age, gender, education level, income level, and residential region across the quintiles of the sum of health literacy scores (Table 1).

caption.p: General characteristics of participants according to the quantiles of the sum of health literacy scores.

sec.title: Association of health literacy scores and demographic and socioeconomic factors
sec.p: Older age was associated with lower health literacy measures (both the sum of health literacy scores and the proportion of correct answers). Female gender was associated with higher health literacy measures in younger age groups, but this trend was reversed in the elderly group (aged ≥ 65 years). Higher education was associated with higher health literacy measures. Higher income level and urban residential region were associated with higher health literacy in individuals with education levels of ≤ Elementary school, but this effect decreased as education levels increased (Fig. 1).

In the multiple linear regression analysis for the sum of health literacy scores, age, gender, education level, and income level were included in the final model (Model 2). The inclusion of residential region (Model 3) did not significantly improve the model (p-value = 0.1333). Elderly (age ≥ 65 year) negatively affected the sum of health literacy scores by − 1.01 when other factors were considered. Female gender had a positive effect (0.93), but elderly females showed a negative effect (− 1.60). Higher education had the greatest positive effect (3.42), followed by higher income (2.05). However, the effect was attenuated in individuals with higher education and higher income, as indicated by the negative coefficient of the interaction term (− 1.21). (Table 2)

In the multivariate ordinal regression analysis for the correctness of the knowledge assessment, age, gender, education level, income level, and residential region were included in the final model. Interaction terms did not significantly improve the model and were therefore not included. Elderly and rural residential region negatively affected the correctness of the knowledge assessment, with odds ratios of 0.39 and 0.73, respectively. Higher education (odds ratio 5.19), female gender (odds ratio 1.46), and higher income (odds ratio 1.24) were positively associated with the correctness of the knowledge assessment (Table 3).

caption.p: The relationship between age group, education level, income, residential region, and the sum of health literacy scores, along with the correct proportion for the health literacy questions. Means and 95% confidence intervals are represented as points and error bars, respectively.
Results of multiple linear regression analysis for the sum of health literacy scores.

table-wrap-foot.p: P-values are calculated using the Wald test between two models. Interaction terms are represented by colons (:).
CI confidence interval, OR odds ratio.

caption.p: Results of multivariate logistic regression for the correctness of the knowledge assessment.

table-wrap-foot.p: P-values are calculated using the Wald test between two models.
CI confidence interval, OR odds ratio.

sec.title: Domain-level analysis of health literacy scores
sec.p: The direction of the effects of demographic and socioeconomic factors was generally consistent across each health literacy measure. Elderly had the greatest negative effect in the Technology and resources domain (Q9-10). Similarly, higher education level had greatest positive effect in the domain. Difference in other demographic and socioeconomic factors was not remarkable between health literacy domains. (Fig. 2)

caption.p: Influence of age group, education level, income, and residential region on each health literacy measure, as measured by odds ratios. Odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals are represented as points and lines. The domains of health literacy measures are abbreviated as follows: disease prevention (A), health promotion (B), healthcare (C), technology and resources (D), and knowledge assessment (E).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of our study revealed that older age (≥ 65 years) was negatively associated with health literacy scores. Female gender was positively associated with overall health literacy among younger individuals but showed a negative association in older age groups. Both higher income and higher education levels were positively associated with health literacy. The model based on the total health literacy score included age, gender, income, and education, along with interaction terms for age and gender, and for income and education. The model based on the knowledge assessment included the same four sociodemographic variables and, additionally, residential region, which was found to be a significant factor. Interaction terms were not included in the final model for the knowledge-based assessment.

Consistent with previous research, older age, lower education level, and lower income level were associated with lower health literacy scores. Interestingly, the effect of gender was positive for younger age groups but reversed in older age. In addition, the effect of region was not significant when education level and income were considered. It is noteworthy that the Technology and Resources domain was more affected by other domains of health literacy, and this trend was further emphasized in the knowledge assessment.

Lower health literacy in the elderly has been an ongoing concern. A previous study highlighted that inadequate health literacy in the elderly is an independent predictor of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular death22. It is alarming that this issue is even more pronounced with digital technologies, and measures to improve digital health literacy are required23,24. The lower health literacy in elderly females may be associated with lower proficiency in mobile device use among females25and it is expected that this trend will decrease in younger age groups.

There has been ongoing debate regarding gender differences in health literacy. A systematic review focusing on individuals with migrational backgrounds suggested that men may have lower health literacy compared to women26. In contrast, another study of hospitalized older patients with chronic diseases found slightly higher health literacy levels in men, though the difference was not statistically significant26. Recent studies on gender differences in health literacy, including digital health literacy, have reported highly variable findings27,28. These inconsistencies suggest that the effect of gender on health literacy may depend on other sociodemographic factors such as age, cultural context, and the specific measures of health literacy used. Our study supports this notion by demonstrating a significant interaction between age and gender in the total health literacy score (Table 2), whereas the interaction effect was not significant in the knowledge assessment model (Table 3; Fig. 2).

The digital divide related to education level is highly concerning. In our analysis, the effect of higher education level was the strongest in both health literacy measures. This trend was most evident in the Technology and Resources domain and in the knowledge assessment based on digital tools. A similar trend has been observed in other countries29,30. It is alarming that this divide could bias the data collection process in clinical trials where digital health technologies are widely and increasingly used31. Therefore, equitable access and the inclusion of diverse trial participants should be carefully considered when implementing digital health technologies32.

The effect of residential region is also noteworthy. As shown in Table 2, rural residential region was not significantly associated with health literacy measured by self-reported questionnaires. However, it was significantly negatively associated with health literacy in the objective knowledge assessment. Therefore, the characteristics of each health literacy measure should be carefully considered when interpreting the results33. Additionally, the results suggest that “sufficient” health literacy reported by participants does not always reflect proper understanding, as similarly observed in a trial using electronic consents18.

We also found that the effects of sociodemographic determinants varied depending on the measure of health literacy used. Notably, the odds ratios for older age (Fig. 2) showed contrasting directions between the health literacy measure Q1 (“Can you assess which vaccinations are necessary?”) and other measures, suggesting a measure-dependent nature of health literacy. Additionally, the magnitude of these effects varied across different measures, with the knowledge assessment showing the largest effect size for older age. Therefore, health literacy results should be interpreted cautiously, considering both individual items and overall trends. This perspective aligns with a systematic review that highlighted the inconsistent correlation between self-reported and performance-based health literacy measures in relation to health outcomes15.

Our study has several limitations. First, the health literacy instrument used (HLIC) was introduced relatively recently. Although it has been validated in a small sample with characteristics similar to those of the KNHANES population, further validation studies are needed. Additionally, as this was the first use of the instrument in the national survey, temporal assessments were not available, which limits the ability to assess the stability of the results over time. Intercultural and interethnic comparisons are also necessary to determine the generalizability of the findings to other populations.

Second, although KNHANES includes a large, nationally representative sample of the general Korean population, it may differ from clinical or patient populations to which the results may be more directly applicable. While the representativeness of the sample could potentially be supported through linkage with nationwide claims data, health literacy was not assessed in patient-based datasets. Finally, the retrospective design of the study limits the ability to establish causal relationships. Further prospective studies in patient populations are warranted to explore the relationship between health literacy and health outcomes more thoroughly.

In conclusion, we demonstrated that older age, lower education level, and lower income level are associated with lower health literacy. The effect of gender on health literacy varies across age groups. The association between age and education level is particularly strong in digital health literacy.
